hierarchy.file_name: Impact--Add evidence + data-source provenance to Positioning Recommendations output.docx

sections.text:
This feature adds lightweight evidence and data-source provenance to each Positioning Recommendation so customers can see what the recommendation is grounded in. Today, recommendations can feel “black box,” especially when inputs are sparse; attaching provenance (top contributing signals/sources, supporting counts, and recency) makes the output more explainable without changing the underlying recommendation logic.

The primary user impact is increased trust and faster decision-making: teams can quickly judge whether a recommendation is based on meaningful, recent inputs (e.g., which CRM fields were used, how many interviews or tickets contributed, and the most recent supporting event). This is particularly valuable for smaller or newer datasets where confidence is naturally lower and users need reassurance before adopting messaging changes.

On the product side, exposing provenance via the recommendations API enables the UI to present “why we think this” context consistently across surfaces (e.g., tooltips, evidence drawers, badges like “Based on 12 tickets; last updated 5 days ago”). It also creates a foundation for future capabilities like confidence indicators, filtering by source, and troubleshooting data gaps—without requiring a redesign of the recommendation engine.

Key success metrics include improved qualitative feedback on recommendation credibility, higher adoption of Positioning Recommendations (views-to-actions or copy/export rates), and reduced support/escalation volume related to “how did you get this?” questions. We should also monitor any performance impact from generating provenance and ensure the evidence remains lightweight, stable, and privacy-safe for all connected data sources.
